column1: 1. abate:  (of something unpleasant or severe) become less intense or widespread
Ex:  the storm abated
2. abscond:  to depart in a sudden or secret manner esp to avoid capture and legal prosecution
Ex:  the cashier absconded with the money
3. acumen:  the ability to make good judgements and take quick decisions
Ex:  she has a sound business acumen
4. adulation:  excessive admiration or praise
Ex:  he found it difficult to cope with the adulation of the fans
5. adulterate:  to reduce purity by combining inferior ingredients
Ex:  the brewer is said to adulterate his beer
6. aggrandize:  to increase in intensity
Ex:  you buy an estate and sink millions of dollars into its improvement
column2: then you are actually aggrandizing the estate

column1: 7. alacrity:  cheerful readiness
Ex:  we accepted the invitation with alacrity
8. anachronism:  something or someone that feels out of place in terms of historical or chronological context
Ex:  the town is a throwback to medieval times
column2: an anachronism that has survived the passing years

column1: 9. approbation:  an expression of approval or praise
Ex:  a term of approbation
10. astringent:  sharp or severe or bitter or acerbic in manner or style;
Ex:  his subversive and astringent humour
11. aver:  to assert or affirm with confidence; to state as a fact
Ex:  he averred that he was innocent of the allegations
12. axiomatic:  taken as given; possessing self evident truth
Ex:  after vietnam
column2: it was axiomatic that the press would approach those in power with a skepticism verging on cynicism

column1: 13. bombastic:  pompous
Ex:  and most live music is bombastic
column2: because that's the only way to make money in

column1: 14. cacophony:  discordant sound; harsh jarring
Ex:  a cacophony of deafening alarm bells
15. canonical:  pertaining to accepted traditions or standards or canons
Ex:  the canonical rites of roman church
16. caustic:  1. (adj) burning or stinging; causing corrosion;
2. (adj) sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way
Ex:  1. a caustic cleaner;
2. the players were making caustic comments about the refereeing
17. chary:  wary; cautiously or suspiciously reluctant to do something
Ex:  she had been chary of telling the whole truth
18. chicanery:  the use of deception or trickery or subterfuge to achieve one's purpose
Ex:  storylines packed with political chicanery
19. complaisance:  the willingness to comply with the wishes of others
Ex:  there are too many complaisant doctors signing sick notes
20. connoisseur:  an informed and astute judge in matters of taste; expert
Ex:  a connoisseur of music
21. contentious:  causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial
Ex:  a contentious issue
22. convention:  a generally agreed upon practice or attitude
23. cynicism:  an inclination to believe that people are motivated purely by self-interest; scepticism
Ex:  public cynicism about politics
24. desiccate:  (adj) lacking vitality or spirit; lifeless
Ex:  a desiccate romance
25. disabuse:  to undeceive or to set right
Ex:  he quickly disabused me of my fanciful notions"
26. discordant:  conflicting or dissonant or harsh in sound
Ex:  the operative principle of democracy is a balance of discordant qualities
27. discretion:  the quality of behaving or speaking in such a way as to avoid causing offence or revealing confidential information
Ex:  she knew she could rely on his discretion
28. disparage:  to belittle or express a negative opinion of
Ex:  she disparaged her students' efforts
29. divulge:  make known to the public information that was previously known only to a few people or that was meant to be kept a secret
Ex:  i do not want to divulge my plans at the moment
30. ebullience:  the quality of lively or enthusiastic expression of thoughts and feelings
Ex:  the ebullience of happy children
31. effrontery:  extreme boldness or presumptuousness
Ex:  one juror had the effrontery to challenge the coroner's decision
32. elegy:  (in modern literature) a poem of serious reflection
column2: typically a lament for the dead'

column1: Ex:  the song passed gradually into an elegy
33. emollient:  1. (adj) attempting to avoid confrontation or anger; calming or conciliatory;
2. (adj) having the quality of softening or soothing the skin
Ex:  1. the president's emollient approach to the differences;
2. a rich emollient shampoo
34. empirical:  based on observation or experiments
Ex:  they provided considerable empirical evidence to support their argument
35. enigmatic:  difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious
Ex:  he took the money with an enigmatic smile
36. ennui:  a feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from a lack of occupation or excitement
Ex:  he succumbed to ennui and despair
37. eulogy:  a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly
column2: especially a tribute to someone who has just died

column1: Ex:  a eulogy to the queen mother
38. evanescent:  ​ lasting for only a short time
column2: then disappearing quickly and being forgotten

column1: Ex:  about a sudden hillside
column3: the evanescent mist hung over the heavy fronds
column4: going out in the sunlight that was breaking through a grey sky

column1: 39. exculpate:  exonerate
Ex:  the article exculpated the mayor
40. exigent:  urgent; pressing; demanding
Ex:  the exigent demand of her contemporaries' music took a toll on her voice
41. extemporaneous:  spoken or done without preparation
Ex:  an extemporaneous speech
42. fallacy:  an invalid or incorrect notion; a mistaken belief
Ex:  the notion that the camera never lies is a fallacy
43. fervent:  having or displaying a passionate intensity or zealous
Ex:  a fervent supporter of the revolution
44. filbuster:  an action such as prolonged speaking which obstructs progress in a legislative assembly in a way that does not technically contravene the required procedures
Ex:  paul has altered the national conversation once before
45. flout:  treat with contemptuous disregard
Ex:  flout the rules
46. fulminate:  express vehement protest or loudly attack or denounce
Ex:  all fulminated against the new curriculum
47. grandiloquence:  inflated
column3: or bombastic in style or expression

column1: Ex:  yet a moment like this seems so overblown
column3: and so self-consciously heroic that it simply stuns me.

column1: 48. hedonism:  the doctrine that pleasure or happiness is the highest good.
Ex:  ibiza was always the place of freedom and hedonism.
49. hubris:  overbearing pride or presumption
Ex:  the self-assured hubris among economists was shaken in the late 1980s
50. hyperbole:  exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally
Ex:  he vowed revenge with oaths and hyperboles
51. idolatrous:  given to intense or excessive devotion or admiration to something; the worship of a physical object as a god
Ex:  america's idolatrous worship of the auto
52. imminent:  impending
Ex:  they were in imminent danger of being swept away
53. impassive:  not feeling or showing emotion.
Ex:  his cold
54. impecunious:  lacking funds; without money
Ex:  a titled but impecunious family
55. imperturbable:  marked by extreme calm
Ex:  the chef was absolutely imperturbable—even when the kitchen caught on fire
56. impetuous:  characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation
Ex:  an impetuous display of spending and gambling
57. impunity:  exemption
Ex:  the impunity enjoyed by military officers implicated in civilian killings
58. inchoate:  just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary
Ex:  a still inchoate democracy
59. incipient:  beginning to happen or develop
Ex:  he could feel incipient anger building up
60. inert:  unmoving; lethargic; sluggish
Ex:  she lay inert in her bed
61. infelicitous:  1. inapt
2. marked by or producing unhappiness
Ex:  1. an infelicitous remark;
2. infelicitous circumstances
62. intractable:  opposite of tractable
Ex:  the most intractable issue of our era
63. inured:  accustom(someone) to something esp. something unpleasant
Ex:  these children have been inured to violence
64. inveigle:  persuade someone to do something by means of deception and flattery
Ex:  we cannot inveigle him into putting pen to paper
65. loquacious:  chatty
Ex:  never loquacious
column2: sarah was now totally lost for words

column1: 66. luminous:  adj softly bright or radiant
Ex:  a sky luminous with stars
67. nascent:  coming into being or in early development stages
Ex:  the nascent space industry
68. nebulous:  vague; cloudy; lacking clearly defined form
Ex:  nebulous concepts like quality of life
69. neologism:  a new word
Ex:  captology is a neologism coined by bj fogg
column2: director of the very soviet-sounding stanford persuasive technology lab.

column1: 70. neophyte:  any new participant in some activity; beiginner
Ex:  four-day cooking classes are offered to neophytes and experts
71. noxious:  harmful
Ex:  they were overcome by noxious fumes
72. obfuscate:  make obscure or unclear deliberately; being evasive
Ex:  the spelling changes will deform some familiar words and obfuscate their etymological origins
73. obtuse:  lacking sharpness of intellect; not clear or precise in thought or expression
Ex:  he wondered if the doctor was being deliberately obtuse
74. occlude:  to obstruct or block
Ex:  your make up occludes your pores
75. odious:  evoking intense aversion or dislike
Ex:  a pretty odious character
76. onerous:  (of a task or responsibility) involving a great deal of effort
Ex:  he found his duties increasingly onerous
77. opprobium:  a state of extreme dishonour
Ex:  opprobrium isn't an action that leads to disgrace
column2: it's something that comes from the inappropriate thing that was done

column1: 78. paean:  a song of praise or triumph
Ex:  a paean of praise for the great poets'
79. pedagogy:  the profession or principles of teaching or instructing
Ex:  pedagogy is recognized as an important profession
80. penurious:  1. (adj) unwilling to spend money
2. (adj) extremely poor
Ex:  1. a tight-fisted
column2: penurious boss whose wage scale is well below other bandleaders;

column1: 2. a penurious old tramp
81. penury:  a state of extreme poverty or destitution
Ex:  economic downturns
column4: and weekends at the high rollers' table in vegas can lead to penury

column1: 82. perfunctory:  done routinely and with little interest or care
Ex:  he gave a perfunctory nod
83. perspicacious:  acutely perceptive; having a keen discernment
Ex:  to exhibit perspicacious judgement
84. pervade:  to permeate throughout
Ex:  .............pervasive verb form.......
85. pervasive:  having the tendency to spread throughout
Ex:  the pervasive odor of garlic
86. phlegmatic:  (of a person) having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition
Ex:  the phlegmatic british character
87. pious:  extremely reverent or devout
Ex:  a deeply pious woman
88. pirate:  to illegally use or reproduce
Ex:  pirated tapes
89. pith:  the choicest or most essential or most vital part of some idea or experience
Ex:  the pith and core of socialism
90. plummet:  to drop sharply or plunge
Ex:  the stock market plummeted
91. polemical:  controversial; argumentative
Ex:  to keep the peace
column3: which usually deteriorates into a polemical argument with uncle bob

column1: 92. prattle:  to babble meaninglessly
Ex:  she began to prattle on about her visit to the dentist
93. precursor:  one that precedes and indicates or announces another
Ex:  a three-stringed precursor of the violin
94. preen:  devote effort to making oneself look attractive and then admire one's appearance
Ex:  adolescents preening in their bedroom mirrors
95. probity:  complete and confirmed integrity; having strong moral principles
Ex:  he enjoys an exaggerated reputation for probity
96. proclivity:  a natural tendency or inclincation
Ex:  he has a proclivity for exaggeration
97. proliferate:  grow rapidly or increase rapidly
Ex:  bunny rabbits have a habit of proliferating
98. pungent:  characterized by strong
Ex:  ammonia has a pungent smell
99. putrefy:  (of a body or other organic matter) decay or rot and produce a fetid smell
Ex:  the body was beginning to putrefy
100. quaff:  drink (something
Ex:  he quaffed pint after pint of good berkshire ale
101. quiescence:  stillness; motionlessness; inactivity; dormancy
Ex:  this method has been shown to induce sleep-like quiescence in adult animals
102. quixotic:  not sensible about practical matters; idealistic and unrealistic
Ex:  as quixotic as a restoration of medieval knighthood
103. rancorous:  characterized by bitter
Ex:  sixteen miserable months of rancorous disputes
104. rarefy:  1. lessen the density or solidity of;
2. make more subtle or refined
Ex:  air rarefies and degrounds the physical body
105. recalcitrant:  marked by stubborn resistance to authority
Ex:  a class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds
106. recant:  to retract esp a previously held belief
Ex:  heretics were burned if they would not recant
107. redoubtable:  (of a person) formidable
Ex:  he was a redoubtable debater
108. refulgent:  radiant or as if radiating light
Ex:  you have refulgent eyes
109. rhetoric:  the art or study of effective use of language for communication and persuasion
Ex:  he is using a common figure of rhetoric
110. salubrious:  a fancy way to describe something that’s good for you or is generally favorable to mind or body
Ex:  one of the less salubrious suburbs
111. shard:  a broken piece of brittle artifact
Ex:  shard is simply a broken piece
112. solicitous:  characterised by showing interest or concern
Ex:  she was always solicitous about the welfare of the students
113. squalid:  (of a place) extremely dirty and unpleasant
column2: especially as a result of poverty or neglect

column1: Ex:  the squalid
114. stoic:  a person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining
Ex:  we knew she must be in pain
115. stupefy:  1. (verb) to stun baffle or amaze;
2. (verb) to put into a state of little or no sensibility; benumb; put into a stupor
Ex:  1. the amount they spend on clothes would appal their parents and stupefy their grandparents;
2. the offence of administering drugs to a woman with intent to stupefy her
116. succint:  short and clear; concise
Ex:  you're going to be interviewed on television about your new book and only have a five minute slot
column2: you'll need to come up with a succinct version of your story

column1: 117. tacit:  implied by or inferred from actions or statements
Ex:  a tacit agreement
118. tenacity:  persistent determination
Ex:  even the most gifted player won't make it to the big leagues without the tenacity required to make the long
column2: hard journey up from the minors

column1: 119. tenuous:  thin
Ex:  a tenuous argument
120. torpid:  mentally or physically inactive; lethargic
Ex:  we sat around in a torpid state
121. trenchant:  sharply perceptive; keen; penetrating
Ex:  trenchant distinctions between right and wrong
122. truculent:  eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
Ex:  the truculent attitude of farmers to cheaper imports
123. ubiquitous:  present
Ex:  his ubiquitous influence was felt by all the family
124. unfeigned:  genuine; opposite of feigned
Ex:  her interest in people was unfeigned
125. untenable:  (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified
Ex:  if your disagreement with your teacher puts you in an untenable position
column2: you better just admit you made a mistake and get on with it

column1: 126. variegated:  having variety of colors
Ex:  variegated yellow bricks
127. vexation:  annoyance; irritation
Ex:  jenna bit her lip in vexation
128. vigilant:  alertly watchful
Ex:  the vigilant eye of the town watch
129. virulent:  1. (adj) bitterly hostile;
2. (adj) extremely harmful or poisonous(disease/poison)
Ex:  1. a virulent attack on liberalism;
2. a virulent strain of influenza
130. vituperate:  1. to speak or write in an extremely negative way about someone;
2. censure severely or angrily
Ex:  on occasion he could stoop to praise one party and vituperate another
column2: but that was his tongue serving his worldly interest

column1: 131. zealous:  avid; marked by active interest and enthusiasm
Ex:  the council was extremely zealous in the application of the regulations
